attribution.name: Chapman, Chris & Withers, A.J.
attribution.note: Source text: A Violent History of Benevolence (University of Toronto Press)

image_credits.license_notes: Most images are Public Domain. James Baldwin (CC BY-SA 3.0, Allan Warren), Neil deGrasse Tyson (CC BY 2.0).
image_credits.full_credits_url: See README.md for complete image attribution table

name: A Violent History of Benevolence: The Deck
description: A 55-card tarot deck examining interlocking oppressions in social work history. Phase 1: Initial 40 figures extracted from Chapman & Withers' 'A Violent History of Benevolence' (2019), Chapter 1: 'Troubling the Standard Account of Social Work'—producing figures from both the 'standard account' (Jane Addams, Mary Richmond) and those erased from it (Ida B. Wells, Claudette Colvin). Phase 2: Recognizing the source text's limitations in addressing Indigenous perspectives and non-Western community care, the deck was expanded with contemporary decolonial voices (Bayo Akomolafe, Vanessa Andreotti, Josh Shrei) and 'The Cracks' (The Grandmother, Preto Velho, The Doula). Phase 3: Organized into four suits with archetypal resonances rather than 1-1 Major Arcana mapping. All figures are complicit. As Bayo Akomolafe says: 'There are always cracks in the systems.'

sections.Description: Figures from the canonical social work history—the names taught in textbooks, celebrated in professional lore. All complicit in interlocking systems of oppression.
sections.Reflection: What violences hide behind the names we are taught to honor?

sections.Description: Those systematically marginalized in social work historiography—erased, footnoted, or sanitized. Their work preceded, paralleled, or challenged the 'standard account.'
sections.Reflection: Whose determination is remembered? Whose is erased?

sections.Description: Indigenous wisdom, spiritual practices, everyday roles—where something else lives. As Bayo Akomolafe says, 'Decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about systems.'
sections.Reflection: What did your grandmother know that no institution taught?

sections.Description: Those doing 'social working' differently today—through philosophy, podcasts, science communication, music. Not a clean alternative, but witnesses to the cracks.
sections.Reflection: What becomes possible when you stop trying to fix?

sections.Context: Hull-House founder, Nobel laureate, early NAACP member who spoke against lynching. Yet also 'called on governments to insist upon health certificates from the applicant for a marriage license' and was 'involved in plans to institutionalize women who had been labelled as feebleminded' (Chapman & Withers, 51). Seconded the 1912 presidential nomination of eugenicist Theodore Roosevelt.
sections.Source: Chapman & Withers argue we should neither 'demonize nor romanticize' Addams—she was both radical AND complicit. 'Our point isn't that we should find another flawless historical figure to emulate' (46).
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The Empress, The World
sections.Reflection: What violences hide behind moral authority?

sections.Context: Created 'scientific casework' to differentiate professional practice from volunteer work. Believed 'social conditions could be wonderfully improved if, to every family in distress, could be sent a volunteer visitor' (Chapman & Withers, 31). Though she grew up a poor orphan, 'much of Richmond's work denigrates poor people as morally reprehensible' (31).
sections.Source: Of poor fathers she called 'married vagabonds': 'To treat the married vagabond as not responsible, is only to increase his irresponsibility' (32). The book argues she was liberal, not conservative—like 'most social work done today' (32).
sections.Reflection: When does structure become a cage?

sections.Context: Bedford Hills Reformatory superintendent. Chapman & Withers cite Nicole Rafter's work documenting Davis's 'central role in incarcerating women on eugenic grounds' (50). Close ally of Addams—'If Jane Addams were President, Katharine Davis would be her Vice President' (51).
sections.Source: Davis 'may well have tended towards the culturally determinist end of eugenic doctrine, but that doesn't place her outside of eugenics' (50). Worked with Addams in 'various social workings, including radical political struggles' (51).
sections.Reflection: What fears drive policies that claim to be rational?

sections.Context: 'Founder of the New York City Charity Organization Society' (52) and close Addams ally through the Anti-Imperialist League and National Consumers League. Rafter documents her 'central role in advancing eugenic criminology policies' that have been 'downplayed or erased in accounts of her life' (50).
sections.Source: 'A social Darwinist organizer of the COS movement, Lowell believed that poverty had its roots in the character of the poor. Pauperism would be eliminated by educating and rehabilitating the poor' rather than through relief (52).
sections.Reflection: How do we reckon with those who did both harm and good?

sections.Context: Founded Carlisle Indian Industrial School, 'the first of its kind' (60). Spoke at the 1892 National Conference on Charities and Corrections—the organization that 'directly became legitimized professional social work' (60).
sections.Source: 'A great general has said that the only good Indian is a dead one… In a sense, I agree with the sentiment, but only in this: that all the Indian there is in the race should be dead. Kill the Indian in him, and save the man' (60).
sections.Reflection: What bondage presents itself as education?

sections.Context: Director of University of Toronto School of Social Work; president of Canadian Association of Social Workers. 'The driving force behind the construction of Canada's first major low-rent rehousing project, Regent Park' (62). In 1963, 'visited Africville for two hours' and wrote a report justifying the relocation (69).
sections.Source: Rose claimed Africville residents were 'ready and to some extent eager to negotiate a settlement.' Chapman & Withers note: 'It wasn't true that people welcomed the relocation; many were adamantly opposed to it' (70). Rose received the Canadian Centennial Medal in 1967, 'during the time of active destruction' (70).
sections.Reflection: What dies when experts decide communities must be 'renewed'?

sections.Context: Professionalization of medicine and social work. Racist medical models.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The Emperor, Wheel of Fortune
sections.Reflection: Who decides what counts as professional knowledge?

sections.Context: Founder and leader of the Indianapolis COS. Published 'The Tribe of Ishmael: A Study in Social Degradation' at the 1888 National Conference of Charities and Corrections (35). 'One of the earliest to instill fear in the general public about both indiscriminate relief and the eugenic threat that poor, disabled, and racialized people posed' (35).
sections.Source: McCulloch compared a poor family to 'a crustacean which has left the free, independent life common to its family, and is living as a parasite, or pauper' (35). His answer to 'What can we do?': 'First, we must close up official out-door relief. Second, we must check private and indiscriminate benevolence… Third, we must get hold of the children' (35).
sections.Archetypal Resonances: Wheel of Fortune, The Moon, The Hanged Man
sections.Reflection: What cycles of harm continue from research done with good intentions?

sections.Context: 'An architect of Canada's Children's Aid Society system' (35). Nancy Christie documents how 'Kelso aimed to convert as many Catholic children to Protestantism as possible. This practice was articulated as motivated by concern for the child' (35).
sections.Source: Part of the broader COS campaign: McCulloch's answer to 'What can we do?' included 'Third, we must get hold of the children' (35). Child apprehension emerged alongside eugenic reasoning about preventing 'unfit' reproduction.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Chariot, The Fool, The Emperor
sections.Reflection: Whose children are 'saved'? From what? For whom?

sections.Context: Credited with coining the term 'social work'—orderly, responsible, disciplined.
sections.Reflection: What is named into existence? What is named out?

sections.Context: Coined 'social worker' in 1900. Believed the poor needed training in proper consumption.
sections.Reflection: Who teaches whom how to live?

sections.Context: Chaired the 1892 conference where Pratt spoke. Nearly invisible now.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The World, The Emperor, The Hierophant
sections.Reflection: What world was built on erased foundations?

sections.Context: Eugenicist president whose nomination Addams seconded.
sections.Reflection: What does 'progress' require? Whose bodies?

sections.Context: 'First articulated eugenic doctrine in 1865 and later coined the actual word in 1883' (34). 'Eugenics became an incredibly popular ideology in which those considered 'fit' were encouraged to reproduce while those considered 'unfit' were discouraged from reproducing' (34).
sections.Source: 'Eugenic framings of 'fitness' were those characteristics already long exalted within moral economies of human value; those considered unfit were diverse members of oppressed groups' (35).
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Devil, Wheel of Fortune
sections.Reflection: What words do we coin that will be condemned?

sections.Context: 'Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.'
sections.Reflection: Who decides what's best for whom?
sections.Quote: Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.

sections.Context: Representing Toronto's Associated Charities (COS), Baldwin 'clearly articulated the movement's drive to eradicate poor people' (34).
sections.Source: 'To keep them in comfortable quarters and allow them to live in idleness is not the way to get rid of them. Hard work and strict discipline… [are] the best means of getting rid of the professional vagrant' (34). A report summarizing his statement called poor people an 'army of tramps that infest this Province' (34).
sections.Reflection: What would it mean to 'get rid of' poverty without getting rid of the poor?

sections.Context: Anarchist revolutionary. Chapman & Withers note that 'a number of socialist and anarchist social justice activists, including Emma Goldman, were eugenicists' (28). Part of their argument that 'liberals and radicals alike, whether Marxist, feminist, anarchist, or other, tended to work for eugenic aims a century ago' (38).
sections.Source: The book argues this complicates the idea that anyone can be 'always and only aligned with justice and the oppressed' (29). Goldman should be 'celebrated for [her] important work... But celebrating [her] work isn't best facilitated by positioning [her] as always and only on the side of justice' (28-29).
sections.Reflection: What blind spots hide in our most radical visions?

sections.Context: 'Black anti-lynching activist and social worker' (60). In 1892—the same year Pratt spoke at the National Conference on Charities and Corrections—Wells 'published Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases, which is a very different kind of social working than that of McCulloch or Pratt' (60).
sections.Source: Chapman & Withers note: 'We can just pause to consider what gets included or excluded in normative social work history' (60). Wells critiqued Booker T. Washington's assimilative measures alongside W.E.B. Du Bois (48).
sections.Reflection: What truth requires courage to speak in your context?

sections.Context: Radical activism, scholarly rigor. Spoke at Hull-House while critiquing its limits.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Hermit, The Star
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to work within institutions you're critiquing?

sections.Context: First woman bank president in America. Made something from nothing within hostile systems.
sections.Reflection: What resources do you have that systems refuse to recognize?

sections.Context: Founded Muslim Women's Association. Imprisoned and tortured for organizing.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hanged Man, Strength, The High Priestess
sections.Reflection: What becomes visible only from a position of surrender?

sections.Context: Founded first Black settlement house in Virginia from her own home.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The Star, The Magician
sections.Reflection: What grows from care that refuses institutional recognition?

sections.Context: First Black woman newspaper editor in North America. Voice of the fugitive.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Star, The Chariot, The Magician
sections.Reflection: What hope sustains when the journey has no guaranteed end?

sections.Context: Co-founded Urban League. Built institutions to address inequality within systems that created it.
sections.Reflection: Can justice be built within unjust institutions?

sections.Context: AME Bishop who brought social gospel to Black churches. Christian socialist.
sections.Reflection: What wisdom comes from standing apart from mainstream success?

sections.Context: Escaped slavery multiple times trying to free his family. Founded Voice of the Fugitive.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Lovers, The Chariot, The Fool
sections.Reflection: What would you risk everything to return to?

sections.Context: Accommodation politics—the middle path that critics called complicity.
sections.Reflection: When is patience wisdom? When is it collaboration?

sections.Context: Self-liberated, self-educated, self-made. Supported feminism.
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to make yourself when the world unmakes you?

sections.Context: 'Nine months before Rosa Parks made her famous stand... Claudette Colvin... refused to move from her seat on a bus' (73-74). Chapman & Withers discuss how movement leaders decided 'she was not the right person to symbolically galvanize a mass movement' (74).
sections.Source: Angela Davis reminds us 'we shouldn't remember these histories through the lens of individualism. Bus boycotts could have been mobilized around Colvin's arrest' (74). The movement was 'built on painstaking organizing efforts and the infrastructure' of collective action (75).
sections.Reflection: Whose determination is remembered? Whose is erased?

sections.Context: Trained NAACP organizer. The staged action that sparked a movement.
sections.Reflection: What gets remembered as spontaneous that was actually organized?

sections.Context: 'Often referred to as Canada's Rosa Parks, was jailed and eventually fined after sitting in a section reserved for whites in the Roseland,' a movie theatre in New Glasgow, Nova Scotia (74). 'A decade before Colvin and Parks wouldn't move from their seats in Alabama' (74).
sections.Source: Now on the Canadian $10 bill—but Chapman & Withers use her story to show how Canadian 'national mythology' claims Canada is 'not a racist country, or at least less so than our southern neighbour,' which 'is untrue' (67).
sections.Reflection: What joy is an act of resistance?

sections.Context: 'The relocations took place from 1964 to 1967, with the final holdout, 'Pa' Carvery, vacating his home in 1970' (70). While Albert Rose received medals, Carvery held his ground.
sections.Source: Chapman & Withers describe how 'many people in Africville were against relocation and the destruction of their community,' contrary to Rose's claims that residents were 'ready and to some extent eager' (70).
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to hold ground when the world insists you move?

sections.Context: Circuit-riding missionary in Buxton fugitive settlement. Nearly invisible to history.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Star, The Hermit
sections.Reflection: Whose knowledge sustains communities while remaining unwritten?

sections.Context: Organized the March on Washington. Erased for being gay.
sections.Reflection: What work happens behind the scenes? Who gets credited?

sections.Context: Writer, witness, exile.
sections.Reflection: What are you refusing to face?
sections.Quote: Not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed until it is faced.

sections.Context: Co-founded Black Panther Party. Free breakfast programs as revolutionary praxis.
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to feed people as an act of revolution?

sections.Context: Transformation upon transformation. Assassinated before Africville was emptied.
sections.Reflection: What would it mean to change your mind completely?

sections.Context: The sanitized dream vs. the radical reality. Assassinated before Africville was emptied.
sections.Reflection: What parts of your heroes have been sanitized?

sections.Context: Troubling relationship with 'untouchable' caste. Contradictions.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, Temperance, The Hanged Man
sections.Reflection: What contradictions do our heroes carry?

sections.Context: The river crossing metaphor. Symbolic radicalization. Icon on t-shirts.
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to 'cross to the other side' when there is no other side?

sections.Context: As Bayo Akomolafe says, decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about systems.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The High Priestess, The World
sections.Reflection: What did your grandmother know that no institution taught?
sections.Quote: Decolonization might be more about grandmothers.

sections.Context: The work that holds the world together. Never counted in GDP.
sections.Reflection: What labor is invisible because it is constant?

sections.Context: The one who shows up. No professional boundary. No billing code.
sections.Reflection: Who shows up for you without being paid?

sections.Context: Holding space at thresholds. Birth and death doulas. The ancient role.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The High Priestess, Strength
sections.Reflection: Who holds space for you at thresholds?

sections.Context: Spirit of enslaved African elders in Umbanda. Slow wisdom. Pipe smoke. Patience earned through suffering.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, The Hierophant, The High Priestess
sections.Reflection: What wisdom comes only through suffering that should never have been?

sections.Context: Indigenous ancestral spirits in Umbanda. Warriors and healers. The forest's knowledge.
sections.Reflection: What knowledge lives in the land that was stolen?

items.name: Pai de Santo / Mãe de Santo

sections.Context: Father/Mother of the saints. Keeper of Axé. Community anchor.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The High Priestess, The Magician
sections.Reflection: What communities anchor you that no institution recognizes?

sections.Context: The ethics Addams admired in poor communities: 'the ready outflow of sympathy and material assistance.'
sections.Reflection: When did someone just show up with what you needed?

sections.Context: The one who asks the obvious question that no one else will ask.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Fool, The Star, The Sun
sections.Reflection: What obvious question are you afraid to ask?

sections.Context: 'The times are urgent; let us slow down.' Nigerian philosopher, psychologist, professor.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Fool, The Hermit, The High Priestess
sections.Reflection: What becomes possible when you stop trying to fix?
sections.Quote: The times are urgent; let us slow down.

sections.Context: Hospicing modernity. 'We cannot continue to consume the world and expect different results.'
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Tower, The Hermit
sections.Reflection: What needs to die so something else can live?

sections.Context: The Emerald podcast. Remembering what was almost forgotten. Ancestral practices.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, The High Priestess, The Magician
sections.Reflection: What have you almost forgotten that wants to be remembered?

sections.Context: Bringing meditation to secular spaces. Also: contradictions and controversies.
sections.Reflection: What wisdom traditions get extracted and repackaged?

sections.Context: Making science accessible. Wonder as public education.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Star, The Magician, The Sun
sections.Reflection: What knowledge do you make accessible? What do you gatekeep?

sections.Context: Brazilian artist weaving ancestral wisdom through contemporary sound.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Star, The Empress
sections.Reflection: What ancestral wisdom moves through your art, your work, your body?
